title: Ford to invest $2B in Louisville Assembly Plant for new EV. What that means for workers
description: The $2B Ford investment promises to create a new Universal EV Platform for assembly, bring a new four-door midsize truck EV to Louisville.
content:
Ford Motor Co. continues to select Kentucky for its newest investments.

Just four months after Ford launched the 2025 Expedition from the Kentucky Truck Plant, Ford CEO Jim Farley was back in Louisville on Aug. 11 to announce a $2 billion investment into the smaller Louisville Assembly Plant off Fern Valley Road.

The investment promises to create a new Universal EV Platform for assembly, bring a new four-door midsize truck EV, and secure 2,200 hourly jobs at the factory, a reduction of about 600 current employees. Workers at LAP are not expected to be laid off. Some workers will be eligible for a buyout, while others may look at a plant transfer to places such as at Kentucky Truck Plant.

"We have plenty of jobs for people," Farley said when asked about the reduction in workforce at LAP as part of $2 billion announcement.

This will be the first time in LAP's history that the plant will produce an electric vehicle and the truck is expected to be available for consumers in 2027, with an anticipated starting price of $30,000.

"The new pickup built here in Louisville is going to cure a lot of problems, like all those generic two row crossovers that dominate our industry," Farley said.

For the past three years, Ford has had a team working on the creation of a new, smaller and more affordable EV product to bring to consumers. This new EV and assembly process stemming from the Aug. 11 announcement is what Doug Field, chief EV digital and design officer at Ford, equated to a combination of "the innovation of the startups, Tesla and Rivian with the ... storied history of Ford."

And as the EV unit of the company has continued to struggle, reporting billions of dollars lost in the second quarter of 2025, Ford is ready to bet on Kentucky to make its next generation EVs.

More: Ford announces $5B investment, 4,000 new EV jobs, with Louisville to produce new EV truck

"There are no guarantees with this project," Farley said from inside LAP on Aug. 11. "We're doing so many new things, I can't tell you with 100% certainty that this will all go just right. It is a bet. There is a risk."

Will Ford close LAP to prepare for EV production?

As part of the $2 billion investment into LAP, Ford will transform the facility from running an assembly line to, instead, using what the company has called an "assembly tree."

This new model of vehicle assembly will feature the new Ford Universal EV Production System and rather than a vehicle being assembled in a straight line from start to finish, the vehicle will be assembled in three parts, front, middle and rear, and will converge at the end to be put into one complete product.

Bryce Currie, vice president of Americas manufacturing at Ford, said two key benefits from this change in how production will be done is that it reduces the amount of parts needed to assemble a vehicle and it makes the job more ergonomic and safer for workers.

The Louisville Assembly Plant will conclude the production of the Ford Escape and Lincoln Corsair later in 2025 as those products' lifecycles come to an end.

The plant will then need to be stripped and retooled to be ready to produce the yet to be named EV truck. Currie said a plant retooling on average takes about 10 months to a year and during this time, LAP workers will go on temporary layoff status. Some workers may be able to work at the Kentucky Truck Plant while LAP is down.

Additionally, Ford plans to build up a stock of Escape and Corsair vehicles to be able to sell through the next 18 months or so as it gears up to produce the new EV truck.

More: Ford announces launch of new electric vehicle, investments in Kentucky and Michigan

Workers will be trained for EV production via a combinination of virtual reality and real life training, Currie said.

Why is Ford making an EV truck at LAP?

In 2023, as part of the negotiations with the UAW, the union and automaker struck a deal that some claimed put Louisville "truly at the center of the universe for EV production and EV innovation," The Courier Journal reported in 2023.

The UAW and Ford agreed to pump major investments and changes into LAP following the end of the production lifecycle of the Ford Escape and Lincoln Corsair in 2025.

LAP was promised a $1.2 billion investment over the life of the 2023 contract and an "all-new EV product." The announcement on Aug. 11 pushes that previously promised investment up to $2 billion.

More: Ford further pushes out production of 2 EVs to focus on affordability

The EV industry has sprouted up quickly across Kentucky, largely due to Ford's investment in the state. Todd Dunn, the president of UAW Local 862 which represents workers at LAP and the Kentucky Truck Plant where Super Duty's are made, previously said "Kentucky is the new Michigan," due to the growth of the EV sector in the state.

Dunn and International UAW President Shawn Fain have previously shared excitement over maintaining a product commitment for LAP and job security for workers.

Will the new EV truck battery be made at the BlueOval park in Glendale?

No. The batteries, a prismatic LFP battery, will be made in Michigan at a battery plant expected to start production in 2026. Ford executives told The Courier Journal the decision to make the batteries in Michigan rather than at the BlueOval SK Battery Park in Glendale was "just a question of scale" and noted that the production of batteries in Michigan for a Louisville vehicle does not replace the company's need for other battery production plants.

LAP first opened in the metro in 1955, assembling trucks. By 1987, truck production had moved across town to KTP and LAP received a $260 million expansion and began producing the Bronco II. Just a few years later in 1990, the Ford Explorer rolled off the line at LAP, and the plant would assemble this SUV and enjoy success for the next decade with sales peaking at 445,157 in 2000.

In 2007, LAP was on the shortlist to be closed as Explorer sales decreased and rising gas prices impacted consumer buying habits. Later that year, the UAW agreed to a new contract with Ford that provided a commitment to keep LAP open.

Explorer production would eventually cease in 2010 and LAP saw a massive $631 million plant renovation. The next year, LAP reopened producing the Escape and by 2013, added production of the compact Lincoln crossover.

By the fall of 2018, Ford started to see a decrease in sales of the once-popular Escape, as competition from other brands in the compact SUV market grew. That same year also saw Ford move 550 jobs from LAP across town to KTP, as the demand for the Super Duty and other large SUV products continued to grow.

In 2019, Ford invested $550 million into LAP in preparation for the relaunch of the Escape, the Courier Journal previously reported. That year, the company also announced it would build the 2020 Lincoln Corsair, a compact SUV, at LAP.

During the pandemic, Ford, like many businesses, saw plant closures and other points of infliction such as workers inside plants testing positive for COVID-19 as the company tried to continue producing vehicles while maintaining safety. In early 2021, as the pandemic continued to cause supply chain chaos, LAP saw work stoppages several times, delaying vehicle production.

In 2023, LAP once again experienced an extended temporary work stoppage fueled by quality control issues with the 2023-model Escape. Nearly 3,200 Ford assembly line workers were out of work for roughly four weeks, and vehicles were not produced during that time period as the company worked to fix a software issue.

On Aug. 11, Ford declared that LAP would secure 2,200 jobs and transform the first facility in the automakers portfolio to the new assembly tree model as the home to the new Universal EV Production System.

Despite the plant's rocky past, LAP is poised to become a future leader in EV production for Ford.

"After decades of rumors about the future of LAP, today, the news harrived, jobs will be here in this plant in Kentucky for generations to come," Gov. Andy Beshear said at LAP on Aug. 11.

Ford Motor Co. to invest $550M in Louisville plants ahead of Escape's relaunch
Amid anxiety about a global recession, slowing vehicles sales and looming job cuts, Ford Motor Co. delivered some good news to Louisville workers Thursday — a $550 million investment in its local factories and plans to retain union jobs.
Most of the spending will go toward upgrading and modernizing the Louisville Assembly Plant on Fern Valley Road as the automaker prepares to release its revamped Escape and Lincoln Corsair models.
No new jobs are part of the deal, according to the Kentucky Economic Development Finance Authority, which granted $40 million in tax incentives in return for the planned spending and a promise to retain 800 full-time workers for at least three years.
Ford promised to plow more than $2 billion into retooling and upgrading its Louisville factories nearly four years ago when it sealed a new United Auto Workers contract.
But most of the attention has been focused on the Kentucky Truck Plant on Chamberlain Lane, where more than $900 million has paid for new robotic riveting and other advanced equipment to build aluminum alloy bodies for Super Duty pickups and SUVs.
Related: Louisville Ford workers vote to authorize strike if needed, union leaders say
The $550 million includes $15 million in new construction at the plants as well as $535 million in equipment and installation costs.
Ford released a statement saying it "builds more vehicles in the U.S. and employs more hourly workers in the U.S. than any other automaker — and we'd like to keep it that way. To do so, we must remain competitive."
The company said that it appreciates Kentucky and Louisville's "strong support" and that the incentives would help Ford remain competitive and support the 12,500-person local hourly workforce.
The Detroit automaker has been working on a new generation of the Escape, a popular compact SUV that it has relied on for sales. But the model has seen slipping sales in the last year amid aggressive competition.
The company's new investment involves several safety features for the luxury Corsair and the Escape, including an Escape hybrid and a plug-in electric hybrid, plus "pre-collision assist" capabilities, warnings for "road departure" and lane changes, and automatic emergency braking.
Much of that technology has become standard in newer high-end cars and SUVs.
Earlier: Ford celebrates 50th anniversary of Kentucky Truck Plant
Louisville Assembly has 3,800 hourly unionized workers, a force trimmed late last year when 500 assembly line employees were transferred to the Kentucky Truck Plant to support a 20% production increase for the Expedition and Lincoln Navigator.
At Louisville Assembly, Ford dropped one of its three shifts and indicated it would cut back production as it modified the plant and retooled for assembling the new models. The plant has been assembling cars and trucks there since the factory opened in 1955.
Since the 2008 recession, the factory has gradually added workers and increased production of the Escape.
Under the finance authority's Jobs Retention Agreement, companies such as Ford, Toyota, GE Appliances and other large manufacturers can receive incentives for continuously upgrading and modernizing their facilities if they agree to maintain payroll levels for Kentucky residents.
The latest "installment" is the fifth for Ford since mid-2007, this time pledging to retain 12,070 jobs of full-time hourly Kentucky workers, an increase from 11,200 in the prior incentive package. Several hundred Hoosiers also work at the factories, so the full-time hourly employment count now is 12,100 plus an undisclosed number of temporary entry-level positions.
The 800 jobs already have been filled, but the company's extended package now requires the investment be made by the end of 2021.
See also: After year of controversy and turmoil, can Shaq help save Papa John's?
"Ford is a longtime pillar of employment in the greater Louisville area and we’re thrilled the company is continuing to reinvest in its plants and retain its Kentucky workforce," agency spokesman Jack Mazurak said in an emailed statement.
"In addition to the tremendous economic impact of its two Louisville plants and their 12,000-plus direct jobs, Ford’s supplier network supports thousands of additional Kentucky jobs," he said.
In recent years, automakers have scrambled to keep pace with an intensifying shift away from more traditional passenger vehicles, such as sedans and compact cars, toward SUVs, pickup trucks and crossovers.
Forbes Magazine has ranked Louisville among the top U.S. cities where manufacturing is thriving, and automotive-related employment and investment is a big part of the resurgence. The Louisville region's manufacturing-related jobs has grown by at least 30% since 2011.
That's significant because of the estimated multiplier effect of $1 spent spurring an additional $1.40 in economic activity.

Ford Motor's history in Louisville through the years
1913: Assembly operations begin in two small shops at Third and Breckinridge streets. Output reaches 12 Model T bodies a day.
1916: Production starts in a four-story brick building on South Third Street, where 7,000 vehicles a year are assembled. The plant closes in 1925.

1987: Ford adds 300 jobs in a $260 million expansion at Louisville Assembly to make a newly designed Bronco II.

1997: A major expansion at the Kentucky Truck Plant — to increase production of the best-selling F-Series trucks — adds about 1,000 jobs.
2000: Ford Explorer sales peak at 445,157.
2002: Louisville's Ford plants are spared from job cuts as part of companywide restructuring.
2007: Ford begins massive restructuring that will close 16 plants in North America. Rising gas prices and popularity of smaller SUVs drive Explorer sales down. Louisville Assembly Plant on closure list.
2007: In new UAW contract, Ford commits to keep Kentucky Truck and Louisville Assembly running. United Auto Workers agree to cut new worker wages to about $15 an hour, while veterans make $28 an hour.
2008: Ford nets $240 million in Kentucky and local tax incentives in trade for a promise to replace faltering Explorer production with more fuel-efficient vehicle and invest in Kentucky Truck.
2008: Ford moves Expedition and Lincoln Navigator Sport Utility Vehicles from Michigan Truck to the Kentucky Truck Plant.
2009: Ford retools Kentucky Truck Plant with new and used robotic tooling imported from closed Ford factories in Norfolk, Virginia and St. Louis, Missouri.
2010: Explorer production ends in Louisville. Ford lays off 1,100 workers on one shift at Louisville Assembly for yearlong, $631 million plant makeover.
2011: Louisville Assembly reopens with new Escape SUV. Louisville Assembly Plant runs on three shifts with 4,500 workers. One third are low-wage UAW hires.
2013: Ford announces it will build a new compact Lincoln crossover at Louisville Assembly.
2014: Kentucky increases Ford's tax incentives by $50 million and the company announces it will invest $80 million at the Kentucky Truck Plant to update the Lincoln Navigator and max out Super Duty production, adding 350 permanent workers. In trade for state aid, Ford agrees to invest $1.8 billion in region by 2017 and max out workforce to 8,700.
2017: Ford announced plans to invest $900 million in the Kentucky Truck Plant to support the production of its latest Expedition and Lincoln Navigator SUVs. That was expected to protect 1,000 hourly jobs. Those cars started rolling off the factory's assembly line later that year.
2019: Ford celebrated the 50th anniversary of the launch of its longstanding Kentucky Truck Plant in Louisville. It also announced it would build the 2020 Lincoln Corsair, a compact SUV, at its Louisville Assembly Plant and would invest $550 million in both its plants in the city, with the state government authorizing $40 million of tax incentives in return. The company also agreed to pay nearly $540,000 to resolve a discrimination case, without admitting liability, after the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission found the Kentucky Truck Plant failed to hire applicants due to disabilities they had.
2020: The coronavirus pandemic hit the automotive industry hard, like it did so many other business sectors. Ford temporarily halted production at both its Louisville factories that year.
2021: Ford announces it will build twin battery manufacturing plants in Hardin County to power its forthcoming lineup of electric vehicles. The $5.8 billion investment, made through a joint venture with South Korea-based SK Innovation, is slated to create 5,000 full-time jobs with production starting in 2025. Meanwhile, both of Ford's assembly plants in Louisville weathered temporary shutdowns as supply chain shortages hobble automakers.

Ford Motor Co. plant in Louisville may have to halt production again
LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Fresh off a one-week shutdown, one of Louisville's Ford Motor Co. plants may be halting production for an additional two weeks as the COVID-19 pandemic continues to disrupt the supply chain.
Ford spokeswoman Kelli Felker confirmed to The Courier Journal on Tuesday that there is a tentative shutdown planned for the Louisville Assembly Plant for the weeks of Jan. 25 and Feb. 1. She declined to comment further.
If the shutdown takes place, roughly 3,900 hourly workers at the plant will be without regular pay for three of the first five weeks of the year. This follows planned annual downtime around the Christmas holiday at the end of last year.
Ford pumped the brakes on work at the Louisville facility last week to "address potential production constraints tied to the global semiconductor shortage," Felker previously told The Courier Journal. Workers headed back to the plant Tuesday.
Louisville economy: Two iconic neighborhood diners say they're 'surviving' pandemic, but business is way down
As with the first shutdown, in the tentative two-week shutdown, UAW workers would receive roughly 75% of their regular pay, Felker confirmed Tuesday.
UAW Local 862 President Todd Dunn told The Courier Journal Wednesday that employees had received a robocall last week about the shutdown and said it is likely, though he added there hasn't been official notification.
When asked about the matter again on Wednesday, Felker said the shutdown is still tentative.
The Dearborn, Michigan, automaker is one of many automobile manufacturing giants, including Fiat Chrysler Automobiles and Volkswagen Group, to feel the pain of the slowdown of semiconductor production.
Semiconductors, or chips, are integral in automobile automation, digital connectivity and security, among other things — powering items from brakes to windshield wipers. And as cars have continually modernized, the reliance on semiconductors also has increased.
Yet as car sales plummeted toward the start of the pandemic, autopart suppliers began to decrease their orders, Bloomberg reported Tuesday. And as these suppliers looked to increase inventory toward the end of the year, they struggled to obtain their desired amount from semiconductor manufacturers.
On Tuesday, Felker did not address an emailed question on whether the tentative shutdown relates to the global semiconductor shortage and what Ford is doing to address it.
The Louisville Assembly Plant produces the company's Ford Escape and Lincoln Corsair. Meanwhile, the Kentucky Truck Plant, off Chamberlain Lane, assembles the Super Duty pickup truck, the Ford Expedition and the Lincoln Navigator.
Ford has not halted production at the Kentucky Truck Plant so far this year.

How long can Ford and carmakers hold off on bigger price hikes due to tariffs?
- Ford CFO Sherry House said the industry can hold prices to a 1% increase through year-end.
- Car buying experts expect to see prices rise greater than that by year-end.
- Automakers reported taking big hits to profits due to tariffs.
It's been four months since President Donald Trump implemented 25% tariffs on all imported vehicles and auto parts, and carmakers have largely been able to offset the extra costs without having to pass it on to consumers — yet.
How long that trend can last depends on whom you ask.
Terence Lau, dean of the College of Law at Syracuse University and former general counsel for Ford Motor Co.'s International Trade and Transactions practice group, put it this way: "The Detroit 3 are being squeezed. The tariff on steel and aluminum, as well as on imported vehicles from their foreign subsidiaries, is hurting them deeply."
It's partly for that reason, experts predict consumers will pay more for new cars across all auto brands. Even if automakers don't substantially increase the manufacturer's suggested retail price, if they pull back on incentives, car buyers end up with higher payments.
Cox Automotive anticipates average transaction prices — the prices customers pay after trade-ins and discounts are applied to the MSRP — will rise 4% to 8% by year-end. J.D. Power has also predicted a 4% boost, or about $1,750 on average, will be added to the average transaction prices of 2026 model year vehicles rolling out later this year.
During Ford's second quarter earnings announced July 30, CFO Sherry House said she has seen a 1% to 1.5% average increase to the prices automakers list their vehicles — called the MSRP — in retail car sales across the industry since tariffs took hold in April. She believes the auto industry can finish out the year without having to raise the list prices beyond that level.
"(Price increases) are probably a bit slower than we anticipated as (automakers) are using up inventory they have before turning to inventory that has higher tariffs on it," House said during a call with reporters. "But we expect that these price increases, of about 1%, will probably hold as we finish out the balance of the year."
A real head-scratcher
House's estimate of the 1% to 1.5% increase on MSRPs across the industry since April is supported by data from Edmunds.com and Cox Automotive — leaving experts scratching their heads.
"That aligns with what we are seeing — at the consumer level, automakers are holding prices," said Mark Schirmer, Cox Automotive spokesman, in an email to the Detroit Free Press.
But he said because of the stable MSRPs and many automakers still offering discounts to keep shoppers coming to dealerships, profits are reduced.
At car shopping site Edmunds.com, Ivan Drury said his data also showed MSRP prices appear to be barely rising in any noticeable way since April.
"Although it seems so contrary to what 'should' have happened," as a result of tariffs, Drury, head of Insights at Edmunds.com, told the Free Press. "Seems like we're still in a transitory stage."
Tariffs and high-income buyers drive up prices
Transaction prices typically increase year-over-year by 3% to 4% as part of normal inflation, Schirmer said. But for the past two years, new-vehicle average transaction prices have been mostly flat or even lower year-over-year in some cases, he said.
Therefore, any increase this year is going to feel like a lot and the expected hike in transaction prices will be the result of tariffs and market mix.
"Right now, high-income buyers are doing much better than low-income buyers, so they have not dropped out of market and that is shifting the mix of new vehicles sold, tilting it higher," Schirmer said. "Thus, the average price paid for new vehicles in the U.S. is higher each month, because of tariffs and because this market is favoring the sale of higher-priced vehicles."
Cox has predicted that this might be the year that the industry sees a month with average transaction price topping $50,000.
"That is a real possibility," Schirmer said. "Last December, prices were $49,000 — so even a modest increase in average transaction prices will get us there."
Data in Cars.com's recently released Industry Insight Report shows inventory trends that support that prediction. It reports that inventory for new cars priced under $30,000, of which 92% are imported, has shrunk for three consecutive months. But it said, "In the $70,000-plus new car segment, the share of imported vehicles increased from 40% in May to 41% in June, suggesting automakers are adjusting for less price-sensitive consumers."
Tariff impact on the Detroit Three
At Ford, House said the company is managing its price increases on a vehicle-by-vehicle, segment-by-segment, basis. She said Ford studies "all the cross-shopped vehicles and we make decisions based on that and how it’s dynamically priced in the market. So we’re pleased with the way we’ve handled it."
Still, the Dearborn-based automaker reported on July 30 that it had $800 million in costs related to tariffs in the second quarter. Ford has said it has an advantage when it comes to tariffs because 80% of the cars it sells in the states are built here.
Yet, for the year, Ford expects tariffs to cost it $3 billion. House said Ford can bring that cost down by $1 billion through pricing on vehicles, production changes, how it brings in imported vehicles and parts and other measures. That puts Ford's estimated net tariff cost this year at $2 billion.
GM, on the other hand, imports about 46% of the vehicles it sells here. The automaker reported Trump’s ongoing automotive tariffs cost the company $1.1 billion in the second quarter and it expects tariffs to cost it $4 billion to $5 billion for all of 2025.
Stellantis reported a $2.6 billion net loss for the first half of 2025, a result the company attributed partly to the cost of tariffs. As an international company shipping vehicles and parts across the globe, Stellantis said it expects to lose approximately $1.7 billion from Trump's tariff policies this year.
Car.com's Industry report said since January, the overall average new vehicle prices have increased by about $100 and U.S.-built vehicle prices are down nearly $200 on average. But imports from the United Kingdom, which accounts for just 1% of available inventory, had the most significant jump of more than $10,000, likely due to tariffs. Imports from Europe, which make up 5% of all inventory, rose by almost $2,500 per car. But many prices fell for vehicles from China, Canada, and South Korea.
A snapshot of average MSRPs
Drury pulled data for the average MSRP on all vehicles with at least 100 units of inventory to compare the average list prices in April with those in July.
At Ford, the Edmunds data showed the vehicle with the biggest percentage mark up in price was the Maverick pickup truck, going up 5.4% from $30,461 in April to $32,104 in July. The all-electric Mustang Mach E was next with a 4.2% hike going from an average list price of $42,229 in April to $43,993 in July.
Ford builds both those vehicles and the Bronco Sport in Mexico, so they are subject to the tariff — or tax Ford must pay on them when they cross the border. In May, Ford told its dealers prices on the Mach-E, Maverick pickup and Bronco Sport would increase by as much as $2,000 on some models. However, the data shows that the average sticker price on the Bronco Sport inched up by only 0.2% or $81 to $33,612 in July compared with April.
The Lincoln Nautilus, which Ford assembles in China, saw its April sticker price of $57,890 rise 1% or $580 to $58,470 in July.
Looking across the rest of the Ford and Lincoln lineup, the average sticker prices for other models have increased by 1% or less. In some cases, prices have dropped. The average list price on a Lincoln Aviator is down 1.3% or $885 in July compared with what it was in April. A Ford Ranger's average list price tumbled by $1,328 or 3.2% to $39,895 in July versus April.
House said in commercial vehicles, there is more pricing pressure, but at this point, "we do think retail may hold given the tariff impact that all of the (automakers) are facing in the balance of the year. We’re not providing anything beyond that point right now. In commercial, we expect it could continue to have pressure."
The average MSRPs for most other brands are similar to the shifts at Ford — some vehicles have seen big percentage price boosts since April, others have not.
The July sticker price for a Chevrolet Tahoe jumped 3% or $2,069 to $71,736 compared with April. But the sticker price on a Chevrolet Traverse is down 0.1% or $62 to $44,648 in July. GM builds both in the United States. It builds the Chevrolet Equinox in Mexico and the MSRP on it dropped by $250 to $30,728 in July, Edmunds data showed.
The Stellantis-made Jeep Gladiator, built in Ohio, had a July MSRP that was 2.5% or $1,131 higher than in April. But the Jeep Compass inched up by a mere 0.3% to $30,025 and it is made in Italy.
The issues automakers face
Beyond the prices on the window sticker, there is the price a customer pays after trade-ins and negotiations: The transaction price.
According to Schirmer at Cox Automotive, Ford's average transaction prices in June, the most recent data Cox has, are down by $1,216 compared with a year ago.
Looking just at Ford, the average transaction price a car buyer paid in June 2024 was $55,662. In June this year, the average transaction price on a Ford vehicle was $54,446, Schirmer said.
Conversely, Ford's average MSRP in June this year was: $58,071, much higher than the transaction price. That's because Ford has been running big sales since April, including its "From America, For America" employee pricing for all that ended earlier this month.
"You can see the issue Ford is facing, like many other automakers: MSRPs are up a lot year-over-year. Average transaction prices are not," Schirmer said. "In fact, Ford's average transaction price in this example is down. When MSRPs go higher (reflective of costs) and average transaction prices go lower (reflective of market), profits take a hit."
Watch incentives, not just prices
Drury said automakers raise MSRPs as the last resort knowing that consumers can absorb only so much before they leave the market altogether.
He speculates that many automakers might be holding off on more immediate price hikes to wait for 2026 model year launches and do it then. Or they could be holding off hoping for either tariff relief from the White House or for other automakers to make the first move.
"There is certainly no advantage to being the first mover in this case," Drury said.
As to how high prices can go before consumers leave the market depends on the vehicle and a person's pocketbook.
"On the sub-$40,000 cars, something like a 5% increase might go 'unnoticed.' But 10% ... might get some customers to balk," Drury said.
Drury added, "The upper price range vehicles like $50,000 and over might have more flexibility, but these are also the vehicles that customers could defect from either the brand or model as there are more options."
Drury said as more of the 2026 models fill dealership lots toward the fall, "maybe then (list) prices could see more movement."
But he noted a critical element to all of this is if carmakers start offering fewer incentives. In that case, the MSRP might not have to change much for carmakers to conserve cash and for car buyers it will still mean monthly payments will likely go up.

KPT, which has seen continued product demand, will begin producing a hybrid electric vehicle of both the Ford Expedition and Lincoln Navigator, as part of the negotiated $750 million product commitment.

"So, we've got more opportunities that they're working on to be able to navigate our membership if affected [by workforce reduction]."
What happens during the contract ratification?
Now that a tentative agreement has been reached, UAW locals that represent Ford workers across the country have started the ratification process. To become the governing contract between Ford and the UAW, members must pass the contract by a majority vote in a democratic election process.

'I felt like a guinea pig.' 45-year-old man relives 38-day hospital battle with COVID-19
COVID-19 took Tony Arms’ job on March 20. He never dreamed a few days later it would threaten his life, too.
Like so many during the coronavirus pandemic shutdown, Arms felt the ripple effect at work well before he felt a tightness in his chest. Once Ford Motor Company shut down production, his job trucking parts for them became irrelevant. The 44-year-old left his final day at work and headed to Kroger across the Ohio River near his Clarksville, Indiana, home. As a diabetic, he knew he was at-risk.
He planned to grab supplies and hunker down with his wife of six years, Cindy Hellman.
He’s a bit of a homebody who works nights. She’s a social butterfly on the day shift, who enjoys line dancing with her girlfriends in the evenings while he's away.
They were finally going to have some quality time together, he thought.
Instead, he’d spend five weeks in a hospital bed fighting for his life without her by his side.
By the time I got Arms and Hellman on the phone in mid-May, he'd been home for nearly a week. He'd dropped 40 pounds in 40 days during his fight with COVID-19. He was grateful for the nurses who cared for him during his isolation, and on top of everything else, he was still waiting for his first unemployment payment from the state.

In more ways than one, he felt like a guinea pig. Kentucky was fumbling with unemployment in a pandemic just as doctors and nurses are trying to get a grasp on COVID-19.

No, they thought, surely they wouldn't do that.
But as Kentucky — and really the world as a whole — settled into its new normal, Arms started with a fever March 31. They treated it with Tylenol and it bobbed up and down until finally it just stayed up. Arms lost his appetite and sense of taste. Mashed potatoes went down OK, but not much else did.
They had a call with a doctor who told him he had all the symptoms of COVID-19, and they informally diagnosed him over the phone.
By April 5, he knew he wasn't going to be able to fight the illness on his own, and he went upstairs and took a shower to cool down. He checked into Clark Memorial Hospital not long after that.
He believes if he'd waited any longer, he would have died.
"There’s no shot for this disease and this virus," he told me. "Everybody that thinks like laissez-faire about it, I can’t tell you how serious this thing is."

She'd gone from being that dancing social butterfly into a total COVID-19 cocoon.
Back at Clark Memorial, Arms had a tube down his throat and no memory of arriving at the hospital. It was April 19, and he'd been unconscious for more than a week. He thought he'd been in a car wreck. He thought he was dying.
First, he heard a man's voice, but he couldn't understand the words. Then he heard a woman, but it couldn't make out what she was saying either.
It was a dream-like hallucination, he told me. He couldn't move his arms, and he couldn't speak.
Then he heard a woman tell him that they were going to take a ventilator out of him, and she pleaded with him to be calm as they unhooked him from the machine. He didn't feel any pain, he told me, just genuine uneasiness.
The ventilator saved his life, but it caused a host of other problems.

For the next several days he struggled to form words. When sounds came from his mouth, they slipped out in whispers or growls. It took almost fives day before he had any voice at all.
He had to relearn how to swallow. The thirst in his mouth was unbearable, and even the slight trace of water from an ice chip would send him into a coughing fit.
"It was the driest (I'd ever been), it was torture," he told me.
At one point, they gave him a cracker, and he thought he'd be able to take it. The next thing he knew the crumbs were flying out of his mouth and the coughing started again.
He had no control over his muscles. His arms and his legs hung limp from days of heavy sedation. First, he needed to build up strength and then he had to will his limbs to do what he wanted them to do.
"You have to kind of push your own boundaries," he said. "Slowly I got movement in my arms and legs."
By late April he was out of the woods, but he still had a long way to go with recovery. The doctors at Clark transferred him to the Frazier Rehab Institute in Louisville. There they lowered his supplemental oxygen and helped him walk again.
Hellman still hadn't seen him in person, but she could watch his progress through videos. Through the screen, she saw him walk 280 feet when just days before he could barely move at all.
She finally brought him home on May 13, more than a month after he first checked into the hospital. He left Fraizer in a crowd of cheers from the doctors and all the staff.
"I hugged him and I cried because he was alive, and I was so grateful that they saved him," Hellman told me.

When I asked Arms what he was most looking forward to now that he was home, he rattled off a list of simple things. Taco Bell was high on that list, he told me, but so was having the strength to do home projects and a little woodworking.
He wanted the nurses that took care of him to know how grateful he was to them for being his family, but he also wanted the hospital and the community to know how overworked they were.
Financially the couple is managing, but they're still calling the unemployment office every day hoping for a check.
Now that things are reopening, he's in talks with his company about what it might look like when he goes back to work. Meanwhile, his wife is building up a collection of fashionable masks to color coordinate with her wardrobe.
He was just fine with a medical mask, he told me.
They both laughed at their differences over the phone.
And as I hung with them, I thought about everything that went into that laugh, from the tube down his throat to that growl and that whisper that first came out after he woke up.
He wouldn't get to hunker down with his social butterfly for the pandemic like he'd hoped, but he'd survived. They had years to look forward to together.
That quality time he was looking for in March just got the extension of a lifetime.

Ford Motor Co. continues to make big bets on an electric vehicle future.
The automaker plans to invest $5 billion and have roughly 4,000 jobs focused on EV production across the Louisville Assembly Plant and the BlueOval Battery Park in Michigan, Ford CEO Jim Farley announced in Louisville on Aug. 11.

"We took a radical approach to a very hard challenge: Create affordable vehicles that delight customers in every way that matters — design, innovation, flexibility, space, driving pleasure, and cost of ownership — and do it with American workers," Farley said.
Utilizing a new universal EV platform built with a new assembly line model, the first vehicle to roll off the line will be a midsize four-door EV pickup truck with a $30,000 starting price coming to consumers in 2027.
Farley called the announcement a "Model-T moment" for the company — a reference to the historic Ford vehicle that essentially launched the automaker 120 years ago. He likened the affordability and adaptability of the Model-T to the newly announced EV platform that the company has worked on for the last three years and said its implications on the market could be just as seismic.
The upcoming production shifts at LAP, which currently builds the Ford Escape and Lincoln Corsair SUVs, appear to lessen the number of jobs on site from 2,800 to 2,200 hourly workers, Ford spokesman Mark Truby told the Detroit Free Press.
Some of those 600 workers may take a buyout offer if they are ready to retire while others can transfer to nearby plants such as Kentucky Truck Plant, but there are no plans for layoffs, Truby said, adding there is "room to grow” with EV production.
The Aug. 11 announcement comes after Ford reported a recent loss of $1.3 billion in the second quarter on the EV unit of the company and announced a further delay in the production of two EV products to 2028.

Farley acknowledged the new "radical approach" and massive investment was a gamble amid a technology crossroads for the automotive industry and international competition.
"The automotive industry has a graveyard littered with affordable vehicles that were launched in our country with all good intentions and they fizzled out with idle plants, laid off workers and red ink," he said. "At Ford three years ago, we set out to break that cycle ... we're talking about a vehicle that can sustain itself, have strong profits, so all of our workers and the community here has actually a sustainable future."
Here's what we know about the historic EV investment from Ford:
What is Ford's Universal EV Platform?
Ford is creating a new Universal EV Platform that will allow a family of "affordable" vehicles to be produced and scaled to meet customer demand.
The new EV platform will allow for a reduction in parts compared to a typical vehicle, create a need for fewer workstations in the plant and improve assembly time by 15%.
Farley said Ford will be the first automaker to use prismatic LFP batteries to power the EVs. This battery type allows for both space and weight savings while being cheaper than other battery types currently on the market.
"Twenty-to-thirty percent less parts, 40% less time in assembly. It's just a radical approach," he said. "We've never built a car this way. There are no guarantees. We have a busy 18 months until we start building this vehicle, but what I am confident about is we've done all the cost of ownership, and it is a radically better proposition for some customers."

What new EVs will Ford make?
The first vehicle expected to be launched from this new universal platform is a midsize four-door EV pickup truck. The automaker is targeting a starting price of $30,000 and the truck will be assembled at the Louisville Assembly Plant off Fern Valley Road.
Ford executives said the vehicle should be profitable within 12 months of launch and will be affordable to consumers not just when compared to EVs but compared to all products on the market.
The truck is expected to be available to customers in the U.S. and overseas in 2027. Ford said the new-to-market truck will be "as fast as a Mustang EcoBoost" and have more passenger space than the competitor Toyota RAV4. Like many EVs, the truck will also feature a "frunk" or front trunk and have a truck bed.

Ford will also deploy a new assembly line model, more than a century after the company first pioneered the moving assembly line. The new Universal EV Production System is expected to simplify vehicle assembly for "safety, quality and speed."
The new assembly line is being coined an "assembly tree" and will feature three sub-assembly lines that run down their own lines at the same time and then join together to make the final product.
The new method, and reduction of parts, has allowed Ford to develop a way for the front and rear of the vehicles to be assembled separately and then combined later down the line with the structural battery, which will be the vehicle's floor.
Parts will now be moved down the assembly tree to workers in a kit that will contain all parts and tools needed, along with instructions for proper use, making the job simpler for employees.
Bryce Currie, vice president of Americas manufacturing at Ford, said the assembly tree model is expected to enhance the quality of the vehicles, thanks, in part, to the reduction of the number of parts used during assembly.
"When you look at what can stop a line or can cause even initial warranty issues, it's the elimination of that," Currie said.
Ford expects this new assembly model to increase production speeds at LAP by up to 40% when compared to the speed of production of the current Ford Escape and Lincoln Corsair, which are currently built on site.
The assembly tree model and universal EV production platform are seen as key components for the future of the automaker that can be married into existing facilities. However, Currie said the universal platform will not be used for big internal combustion vehicles such as the Super Duty trucks made at Kentucky Truck Plant.
What investment is Ford making in Louisville?
With its new $1.9 billion project, Ford will expand LAP by 52,000 square feet and upgrade the plant's digital infrastructure. This will make LAP the fastest network with the most access points for quality control scans of any Ford plant across the globe.
The Courier Journal previously reported Ford had filed plans to Louisville Metro Planning and Design Services in June that detailed the addition of new docks and large EV charging station.
The project, the third-largest economic development project in the state's history, secured $120 million in tax-based incentives at a special meeting Aug. 11 of The Kentucky Economic Development Finance Authority.

This supplemental project adds to an existing Kentucky Jobs Retention Act program agreement between state government and the company. The performance-based incentive allows the company to recover up to a cumulative $550 million based on the company’s overall $5.55 billion-plus investment.
By hitting annual investment and job targets, the company can be eligible to keep some of the new tax revenue it generates by claiming eligible incentives against its income tax liability and/or wage assessments, according to the state.
Will Louisville see new Ford jobs?
Currently, LAP has 2,800 hourly workers and 200 salaried workers, a Ford spokesperson said.
The announcement from Aug. 11 indicates the EV project at LAP will start with 2,200 employees — 600 fewer hourly jobs than are there currently.
Ford spokesperson Mark Truby said the company is not planning layoffs but instead some workers will likely take a buyout offer while others will have the option to transfer to the Kentucky Truck Plant or “other plants in the area.”
“This project will start with 2,200 hourly workers, so 600 fewer workers than we have today, but it’s a lot of headroom to grow,” Truby said. “There’s nothing to say today that this is the only top hat to be built in Louisville, but we’re focused on this product today and there is room to grow.”
Why is the Louisville Assembly Plant getting a new EV product?
During the 2023 contract negotiations with the UAW, which eventually led to Ford workers across the country being called out on strike, the union and automaker struck a deal that some claimed put Louisville "truly at the center of the universe for EV production and EV innovation," The Courier Journal reported in 2023.

The UAW and Ford agreed to pump major investments and changes into the Louisville Assembly Plant following the end of the production lifecycle of the Ford Escape and Lincoln Corsair.
LAP was promised a $1.2 billion investment over the life of the 2023 contract and an "all-new EV product."
The EV industry has sprouted up quickly across Kentucky, largely due to Ford's investment in the state. Todd Dunn, the president of UAW Local 862, which represents workers at LAP and the Kentucky Truck Plant where Super Duty trucks are made, previously said "Kentucky is the new Michigan," due to the growth of the EV sector in the state.
In June, documents filed with Louisville Metro Government showed Ford is already in the early stages of retooling LAP to go from producing gas powered vehicles to EVs with the planned addition of 12,000 square feet of canopy to shelter 16 charging units and a substation, The Courier Journal first reported.
Dunn and International UAW President Shawn Fain have previously shared excitement over maintaining a product commitment for LAP and job security for workers.

"We got a plant that's got security, we got a United States that's got the security of having a product, ... we've significantly increased the wages, we've got a contract that's the best contract we've seen in two decades," said President of UAW Local 862 in Louisville Todd Dunn.

LAP first opened in the metro in 1955, assembling trucks. By 1987, truck production had moved across town to KTP and LAP received a $260 million expansion and began producing the Bronco II. Just a few years later in 1990, the Ford Explorer rolled off the line at LAP, and the plant would assemble this SUV and enjoy success for the next decade with sales peaking at 445,157 in 2000.
In 2007, LAP was on the shortlist to be closed as Explorer sales decreased and rising gas prices impacted consumer buying habits. Later that year, the UAW agreed to a new contract with Ford that provided a commitment to keep LAP open.
Explorer production would eventually cease in 2010 and LAP saw a massive $631 million plant renovation. The next year, LAP reopened producing the Escape and by 2013 added production of the compact Lincoln crossover.
In 2019, Ford invested $550 million into LAP in preparation for the relaunch of the Escape, the Courier Journal previously reported. That year, the company also announced it would build the 2020 Lincoln Corsair, a compact SUV, at LAP.
Despite the plant's rocky past, LAP is poised to become a future leader in domestic EV production for Ford.
"Louisville has been a Ford Motor city, we still are a Ford city, and this agreement makes it very clear, we will continue to be a Ford city," Greenberg said.

It noted that Expedition retail sales are up 36 percent from a year ago, while Lincoln Navigator sales are up more than 80 percent from this time last year.

The company also dialed back production of its higher-priced Lincoln MKC at the assembly plant, which is on Fern Valley Road near Interstate 65. Ford informed suppliers and employees in June that a full-size electric pickup, which is to be the successor to the F-150 Lightning, will be delayed to 2028, a company spokesman told the Detroit Free Press on Aug. 8. That's a delay of a few months longer than the initial delay set for late 2027. Prototypes for that vehicle will still launch in 2027. Ford plans to make that vehicle at its BlueOval City Assembly Plant in Tennessee.
Additionally, Ford is delaying production of its E-transit van, to be built at its Ohio Assembly Plant in Avon Lake, Ohio, from 2026 to 2028.
“F-150 Lightning, America’s best-selling electric truck, and E-Transit continue to meet today’s customer needs," Ford spokesman Ian Thibodeau said in a statement. Ford Motor Co.'s two large factories in Louisville won't restart production on Monday after all — and the company hasn't set a date yet for when its workforce will return to the assembly lines.
That means that at least 13,400 hourly employees in Louisville will remain idle during what may become an extended shutdown.

Ford operates Louisville Assembly Plant on Fern Valley Road, where compact SUV Escape and Lincoln Corsair are assembled; as well as Kentucky Truck Plant on Chamberlain Lane, where Expedition, Lincoln Navigator and F-250 and larger pickups are assembled.
Autoworkers are used to temporary shutdowns for plant re-tooling and maintenance in the summers and after the holidays. But an extended layoff with no end in sight will require idled employees to file for unemployment and wait out when they can return to work.
The United Auto Workers union contract provides some unemployment supplement to boost regular jobless benefits for qualified full-time workers. The benefits delivers about 75% of full pay for many with more than a year on the factory floor. Employees with less than one-year seniority or who work as temporary workers can file for unemployment, benefit of which are based on their current earnings.
Ford has been backed into a corner as a result of the shutdowns. It's already shaky financial performance in recent quarters will only worsen when the company isn't running its factories. Reports out this week also indicate Fitch Ratings, the large credit rating agency, has downgraded the issuer default ratings of Ford and its subsidiary Ford Credit from BBB- from BBB.
A downgrade usually follows a poor outlook for the company's operations, its future outlook or its industry. In the case of COVID-19, Ford and many other industries are dealing with all three issues that are certain to hammer earnings.
Louisville workers are being reassured that the union and the company are looking out for the safety, UAW Local 862 president Todd Dunn said in a text. The shutdown doesn't just affect Ford workers and their families. The supplier operations that support Ford, which supply seats, lighting, door paneling and consoles, also employ several thousand employees in Michigan and across the region.
